10.5 Identity Politics

Claims arising from political movements made up of recipients of
psychiatric care call for a seat at the policy-makers’ table;
representational authority in the co-production of knowledge based on
first person experience of psychiatric symptoms and treatment;
attention to complaints of unjust treatment by the
“survivors” of diagnosis and care; equality of mental with
other disabilities, and or mental with other medical conditions;
recognition of neuro-atypicality from proponents of a neurodiversity
model of disorder (Ortega 2009; Polvora 2011); and from “mad
pride”, the claim that madness is an attribution from which to
draw strength and cultural identity. Largely neglected until now
within psychiatry or philosophical writing, the claims of mad pride
have recently been critically evaluated and related to the social
theory of philosophers like Honneth and Taylor (Rashed 2019,
2021).
